bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Wilbur A. Sawyer, June 29, 1948

div1.p: Hench has edited the manuscript and selected photographs for the publication of his Washington, D.C. lecture.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Wilbur A. Sawyer, June 29, 1948
div1.opener:
June 29, 1948
Your reference No.: IC 512.819
Dr. Wilbur A. Sawyer
Secretary General
Fourth International Congress on Tropical Medicine
Department of State
Washington 25, D. C.
My dear Doctor Sawyer:
div1.p:
On the evening after I gave my talk in Washington, you told me you
wanted the manuscript edited and the photographs selected and returned to you
almost immediately. Regretfully I had to tell you that I was going to be away
from town for some time. I have just returned from the east and have quickly
made a few corrections to the copy of my manuscript which you sent to me. Most
of the changes are very minor but the two inserts quoting contemporaneous Wash-
ington newspapers which were not in the original draft I am anxious to have in-
cluded.

If at all possible, I would like to have the article illustrated and
I am offering you five photographs for your consideration. These are numbered
on the back.
Number 1 is an 1873 newspaper cartoon illustrating the horrors of a
“plague-stricken city”; namely, Shreveport in the epidemic of 1873.
Number 2 represents one of the southern epidemics of 1888 and illustrates
the shotgun quarrantine of yellow fever in Florida.
By separate post I will be sending you an enlargement of the central
view of Number 3, showing Canal Street, New Orleans deserted except for hearses
during one of the epidemics of yellow fever, with a pall of smoke from the tar
pots and cannon fire hanging over the city.
Number 4: I will send you in a day or so also an enlargement of the
lower central view showing the piling up of the unburied coffins.
Number 5 shows the remains of Building Number 1 as I visited it just
recently in March, 1948. Dr. Pedro Hogueira of Havana is on the left (He was
one of the official delegates to your Congress.); Johnny Moran is in the middle
and I am on the right.

If you decide to select only three, I will let you choose. My own
preferences would be Numbers 1, 3 and 5.

I have an ulterior motive in offering Picture No. 5, the current remains
of Building Number 1. I would like the present generation of physicians to realize
that Camp Lazear has been rediscovered and that Building Number 1 still stands.
As you know, I have waged a campaign to memorialize the camp and preserve Building
Number 1. I believe I have been successful as the Cuban Government recently set
aside $50,000 as a preliminary sum for the preservation of the camp site and
building, but I am anxious to have those interested in tropical medicine know
about this.

Will reprints be available? When we receive proof we will read it,
correct it and return it promptly by air mail, if you wish. Please address it
to me but I will have it returned through our Editorial Department and at that
time we can order the desired number of reprints. You will note that at the
bottom of the manuscript I inserted the sentence “An illustrated lecture presented
before.....” It may be that you will not wish to have the last part of that sentence
on the original printing, since obviously the proceedings is that of the Congress,
but I would like to have at least the first three words printed in the proceedings;
namely, “...An illustrated address”. We could have the whole sentence appear on
the reprints.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
